author: Adriaan Kruger
title: Nvidia and its friends boost SA unit trusts - Moneyweb
text:
A quick look at the performance of unit trusts in 2024 shows that no fewer than 26 unit trusts in SA achieved returns of more than 30%. More than 100 chalked up returns of more than 20% over 12 months.
The best-performing unit trust ended 2024 with an annual return of nearly 72%, the second best with 68% and the third with 54%, while 10 unit trusts spoilt investors with total returns of 40% and more.
Read: JSE’s best and worst shares of 2024
The best of the bunch with the 72% return was the Raven BCI Worldwide Flexible Fund , according to the Profile Data published on Moneyweb.
Downloading the fund’s fact sheet shows that this beautiful return was due to a big investment in the US tech giant Nvidia – which increased by close to 165% from $53 in January to $140 at the end of 2024.
Listen/read: Nvidia vs China tech: A $3.6trn giant in perspective
The fund did even better by investing in AppLovin Corporation, a tech company that facilitates the development and publishing of software applications.
AppLovin gained a massive 741% from beginning January to end December 2024.
The Saltlight SNN Worldwide Flexible Fund can also thank AppLovin for its gain of 68% during 2024. It had an investment in Sea Limited, which produces online games and entertainment, which returned 187%.
Closer to home, the Saltlight fund got a return of 114% by investing in WeBuyCars and 97% from its punt on Kar . Blue Label Telecomms, Brookfields Corporation and Roblox Corporation earned the fund close to 50% each.
Brookfields is also an interesting investment. It claims to be the world’s biggest alternative investment manager.

FAANG fund
US technology shares were also behind the good performance of the next few unit trusts on the list.
Sygnia FAANG Plus Equity Fund obviously had Nvidia, and earned 71% from Meta Platforms, 47% from Amazon.com and 37% from Alphabet Incorporated.
FAANG stocks also delivered for the Momentum GF Global Sustainable Equity Feeder Fund , while it had an investment in JP Morgan that returned 43%. Its investments in Novo Nordisk and Merck & Company unfortunately lost 14% and 16%, respectively.
US tech stocks also boosted the next two unit trusts on the list – another Sygnia fund based on FAANGs ( Sygnia Itrix AI Actively Managed ETF ) and the RCI BCI Worldwide Growth Fund .
The next one – the Ninety One Value Fund , which boasted a return of 41% – deserves a special prize.
Its fund managers and analysts achieved this remarkable return by chasing value shares on the JSE.
The largest holdings in the portfolio include Absa, Life Healthcare Group, AECI, Italtile, Brait, Netcare, Pan African Resources, Datatec, Caxton & CTP Publishers and Printers, and Altron.
The losers
The list of the unit trusts that were the worst performers during 2024 does not need a lot of analysis.
It also needs to be said that the portfolio managers are not to blame for the bad performance.
The laggards include several funds that invest in commodities and resources, international bonds, and international property trusts. Their time will come.
The Montrose BCI Flexible Fund of Funds unit trust lost its investors nearly 9% due to its investments in funds that hold US and other bonds.
The Legacy Africa Regional Equity Prescient Fund had a horrid time investing in businesses that operate in Africa.
This fund’s objective is to invest in companies that generate more than 50% of their revenue on the African continent (excluding SA).
Around 38% of the fund was invested in Egypt, 20% in Kenya and 10% in Morocco. Nearly 50% of the investments were in financial companies, but that the fund had nearly 20% in cash (June 2024) hints that there are not many opportunities in Africa.
The fund is also very small. The fact sheet dated end June 2024 disclosed that it only had assets of R32 million.
The PSG Global Equity Feeder Fund got it wrong too. Its biggest investments – in Prudential plc, Anheuser-Busch InBev, Shell, Glencore and Babcock International Group – did not perform well. As a result, investors were about 8% poorer than they were in January 2024.
The majority of the funds that performed badly included commodity funds, international property and international bond trusts.
